ud7.10:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ud7.10:1.3: Now at that time, while King Udena was visiting a park, his royal compound burned down. Five hundred women died, with Queen Sāmāvatī at their head.
ud7.10:2.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Kosambi for alms.
ud7.10:2.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him had happened. They asked the Buddha,
ud7.10:2.5: “Sir, where have those laywomen been reborn in the next life?”
ud7.10:3.1: “Among those laywomen there were stream-enterers, once-returners, and non-returners.
ud7.10:3.2: None of those laywomen died without some fruit of the practice.”
ud7.10:4.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud7.10:5.1: “The world is caught up in delusion,
ud7.10:5.2: but is looked on as making sense.
ud7.10:5.3: The fool caught up in attachment
ud7.10:5.6: but for one who sees, there is nothing.”
